header.title: O livro de G.O. Mebes com ilustrações dos Arcano Maiores

central_thesis: The central thesis is the comprehensive presentation and detailed esoteric interpretation of the Major Arcana from G.O. Mebes' 'Curso de Enciclopédia do Ocultismo', published in Shanghai in 1937. This work offers a unique Hermetic-Qabalistic framework for understanding the Tarot, characterized by distinctive symbolism, non-standard numbering, and a 'mirror-like' reflection of reality within its imagery, aiming to guide practitioners through profound contemplation and spiritual insight.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina 1: Arcano da Unicidade e da Individualidade (The Magician)
structure_content.summary: This card depicts a standing male figure emerging from blue-lilac turbulences, positioned behind a dazzling white cube-shaped table. On the table are a coin, a cross-hilted sword, and a crystal chalice. The figure, whose lower body is hidden by the table, has an infinity symbol above its head, a golden ribbon on its forehead, and a white cloth covering its neck. Its body is bare except for a gold belt, showing planetary characteristics. The left arm holds a hazelnut wand, while the right arm gently rests on the table. The overall impression is one of profound, yet non-concrete, reality.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina 2: Gnose, Porta do Santuário, Papisa (The High Priestess)
structure_content.summary: Set within an Egyptian temple, a large dark violet velvet curtain, supported by a gold bar, hangs between two columns: red on the right, blue on the left, both made of stone blocks on solid bases. Three beige-grey sandstone steps lead up to a cube where a veiled woman sits. A band encircles her forehead, extending into a semi-transparent veil covering her face to the chin. A violet silk tunic drapes from her shoulders, exposing her chest and upper body, revealing a golden solar cross between her breasts. She holds a half-unfolded papyrus scroll. An Egyptian adornment of cow horns forming a lunar crescent, with an opaque silver disc (full moon) between them, rests above her head. The scene is airy but dimly lit from the front.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina III: Vênus Urania, Physis, Imperatriz (The Empress)
structure_content.summary: Against a blue dawn sky and a convex terrestrial globe, a semi-transparent grey cube supports a reclining female figure, whose contours blend with an intense gold-orange light on the right. She is of a pure Venusian type, with loose brown hair and an expression of both pain and happiness, reminiscent of childbirth. Dressed in a soft green tunic, she holds a triangular, rounded shield with a flying eagle bearing a Hierophant's cross in its beak. Her right arm raises a golden scepter topped with the Venus symbol. Her feet rest on a crescent moon, and twelve stars form a cord above her head. The image is colorful and luminous, with soft, contrasting colors.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina IV: Forma, Autoridade, Adaptação, O Imperador (The Emperor)
structure_content.summary: The scene features two white angular walls decorated with sapphire blue swastikas, and a grey square stone floor. A white cube with an eagle in flight and the Hierophant's Cross around its neck is on the floor. A man, seen in profile, leans casually on the cube, his bent leg forming a cross. His left arm extends, holding a golden scepter with a Venus symbol, containing a silver Jupiter symbol. He wears a sapphire blue tunic, golden sandals, an Assyrian beard, and a triple golden Egyptian tiara. The figure embodies a strong Jupiterian type, conveying power and authority. Lines are clear and distinct, lit from the bottom-left.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina V: O Mestre dos Arcanos, O Grande Hierofante, O Papa (The Hierophant)
structure_content.summary: Inside an Egyptian temple, two columns flank the scene, with the left partially lit. Five steps lead to a platform where a slightly forward-leaning man sits, dressed in a white sacerdotal robe with a white belt. His head is adorned with a five-branched horned crown, similar to Arcana II. He holds a long staff in his right hand, topped by a large Hierophant's Cross. His left hand is extended in a gesture of authority and blessing. On the grey rectangular stone floor, two kneeling male figures face him: one clear and slender with light brown hair, the other darker and stouter with black hair. Light enters from the left, creating five distinct patches on the floor. The image conveys authority and voluntary submission, with soft contours.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina VI: Bifurcação, Livre Arbítrio, O Enamorado (The Lovers)
structure_content.summary: The background is a rocky landscape, with a gentle, flowery path on the left slope and a steep, barely visible rocky path on the right. At the crossroads, a young man in white sacerdotal clothing and brown shoulder-length hair holds the hands of two women. The left woman, in a rich, colorful tunic (brown and dark green) with loose red-copper hair and irregular features, leans back, inviting the man down her path. The right woman, fully covered in a golden tunic with a severe face and regular features, points to the rocky path. Above the man, a genius hovers with a drawn bow, aimed at the left woman. The sky is clear, with good air and perspective.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina VII: Círculo Hermético, Carruagem (The Chariot)
structure_content.summary: Set on a portion of the terrestrial sphere, a golden cubic chariot, whose wheels are adorned with eyed golden rims, is pulled by two winged sphinxes: black on the left and white on the right, pulling in opposite directions but looking at each other. The front of the chariot features a sculpted Litigam and, above it, a winged solar disc flanked by two small serpents. A blue canopy with golden pentagrams surmounts the chariot, supported by four columns (gold, silver, lilac, red). Standing in the chariot is 'The Victor,' whose facial features resemble those of Arcana I but with more pronounced planetary influences. He wears a seven-pointed crown with three pentagrams and fish-scale armor with three squares and two lunar crescents on the shoulders (right clear, left dark). His left hand holds a staff topped by a sphere supporting a cube and a triangular pyramid. His right hand holds a sword pointing downwards. The Victor is lit by a strong solar ray, shifting colors from yellow/red to silver/green/blue across the background. The details are clear and well-defined.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina VIII: Equilíbrio, Lei, Justiça (Justice)
structure_content.summary: Against a blue sky, two Corinthian columns frame the scene: silver on the left, gold on the right. The floor is marble. A woman, resembling the Greek goddess Hera, sits slightly forward between the columns. She wears a white Greek tunic, a blue ribbon, and a Hellenic hairstyle with a gold ribbon. Her eyes are covered by a semi-transparent white cloth. A golden chain and solar cross adorn her chest. In her right hand (reversed in the image), she holds a sword pointing downwards, positioned near the silver column. Her left hand extends a golden balance with an alate disc for its crossbar, perfectly centered with balanced pans. The scene is airy and bright, with distinct lines.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina IX: Luz Oculta, O Eremita (The Hermit)
structure_content.summary: A dark night sky, brighter with small stars but no moon, reveals an old man enveloped in a coarse cloak, forming three folds that cover his entire figure. In his right hand (not reversed in the image), extended and partially covered by the cloak, he holds a lantern with three flames illuminating his white-bearded, grave yet benevolent face. His forehead, ears, and hair are covered by a hood. In his left hand, he holds a shepherd's staff with three visible wooden knots. A small fleeing snake is at his feet. The overall tone is very dark but not somber, with all light emanating from the lantern.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina X: Testamento, Reino de Deus, Esfinge, Roda da Fortuna (Wheel of Fortune)
structure_content.summary: The background is the interior of a multicolored sphere. Below, a undulating lead-colored sea without foam. At the center, a support bar rises, around which two silver serpents entwine to form a caduceus with two coils. In the middle of the bar, an indefinite-colored wheel is fixed, circumscribing two triangles (one ascending and clear, one descending and dark) forming a hexagram. On the right side, a human-bodied, dog-headed Hermanubis ascends, holding a golden caduceus. On the left, a dark red to almost black crocodile-bodied, human-headed Typhon descends, holding a bident pointing downwards, with an emerald green tail wrapped around the circle. Atop the wheel, a winged sphinx rests, facing forward, with calm, severe features, holding a sword pointing upwards in its left paw. The figures are calm, severe, devoid of passion. The sphinx's left paw holds a sword pointing upwards.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XI: Leão Dominado, A Força (Strength)
structure_content.summary: On a vast lawn beneath a blue sky, a young girl, almost childlike, stands clearly visible. Her Martian-Venusian face is pure and innocent, with loose gold-copper hair. An infinity sign, woven from light, shines above her head. She wears a white tunic down to her feet, with her left knee slightly bent. A large gold pentagram, secured by a chain of smaller silver pentagrams, adorns her chest. A vibrant purple cloak, lined with lilac, is draped over her shoulders. In front of her, a lion with an open jaw. Her hands are placed between the lion's teeth, as if effortlessly opening or closing its mouth. The lion's position is secondary; the crucial element is the girl's pure devotional expression, which grants her incredible strength to tame the beast. Contours are clear and lines well-defined.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XII: O Sacrifício (The Hanged Man)
structure_content.summary: Above a clear, clean forest, a blue sky. In the foreground, two tree trunks, cut at 3-4 meters, show vestiges of six pruned branches. A crossbeam resting on the trunks forms the letter Thau. From this beam, a naked man hangs upside down by his left foot, with only a piece of cloth around his loins. His right leg is bent, forming a cross with his left leg. His hands are tied behind his back, creating an inverted triangle with his arms and head. His face is identical to that of the man in Arcana I, but with the expression of a crucified Christ. His loose hair descends, spreading into golden rays that condense into gold coins upon reaching the ground. The figure's overall position clearly outlines the symbol of the Great Work: a cross above an inverted triangle.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XIII: Imortalidade em Essência, Morte e Reincarnação, A Foice, A Morte (Death)
structure_content.summary: A gray autumn sky hangs over a plain where a skeleton, Death, advances from right to left, wielding a scythe. It cuts down everything in its path, with its left foot crushing a reaped female head. To its left, a crowned male head is also cut down. Everywhere, heads, grass, and flowers are mown. Behind Death, in the reaped field, infant hands and feet emerge from the soil; thirteen such 'sprouts' are visible in total. The overall impression is sad and heavy, conveyed by monotonous, almost faded colors. The figure of Death itself shows no expression.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XIV: Engenho Solar, Dedução, Temperança (Temperance)
structure_content.summary: Against an intensely blue summer sky, a luminous winged human figure, with swan-like wings, hovers perpendicularly to the horizon. The face is androgynous, of a solar type. A gold ribbon encircles its forehead, and a broad gold belt supports a narrow white skirt reaching mid-thigh. In its right hand (not reversed in the image), the figure holds a golden pitcher tilted downwards, from which seven-colored liquid flows into a silver pitcher held in its left hand. The vibrant rainbow colors fade and dim as they approach the silver vessel. The figure is very luminous and prominent, creating a strong contrast with the deep blue sky.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XV: Lógica, Serpente, Baphomet, Diabo (The Devil)
structure_content.summary: The background consists of dark, swirling grey clouds, which cluster at the bottom to form a lead-colored terrestrial hemisphere. Firmly inserted into the curvature of this terrestrial arc is a cube upon which Baphomet sits. Baphomet has a goat's head with erect horns, horizontal ears, and a pointed beard, forming an inverted pentagram, though an upright, evolutionary pentagram is on its forehead. A censer with three flames connects superiorly. Baphomet's eyes are tender, its torso scaly and feminine, with large aquiline wings. The masculine left arm, bearing 'solve', points to a clear crescent moon. The feminine right arm, bearing 'coagula', points to a dark waning moon. Its goat legs are crossed, with hooves resting on the terrestrial sphere. A caduceus rises from its groin, with silver serpents and a gold shaft, its sphere at Baphomet's solar plexus level. In front of Baphomet (slightly displaced), two naked figures, a man (hands crossed behind back, head bowed in despair) and a lunar woman, are bound by an iron chain around their necks and pelvis, respectively, expressing slavery and despair. The scene gives a deeply sad and discouraging impression.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XVI: Torre Destruída, Torre Fulminada, Casa de Deus (The Tower)
structure_content.summary: The background is a tilled field under a sky of dark, menacing clouds. In the middle, a tall, windowless stone tower is struck by lightning, causing its upper part to crumble. Two human figures fall with the debris: the first, closer to the ground, is crowned, falling headfirst with outstretched arms and open legs, graphically representing the letter Ain. The second, uncrowned, falls without forming any symbolic figure. The image conveys an impression of definitive, catastrophic destruction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XVII: Esperança, Intuição, Adivinhação Natural, Estrela dos Magos (The Star)
structure_content.summary: A night sky with seven eight-pointed stars, the largest and brightest at the center, surrounded by six smaller ones forming a crown. Below, a sandy desert transforms into a flourishing garden with roses, lilies, and lotuses around a naked Mercurian-type girl. She kneels with one knee on the ground, pouring liquid from a golden jar in her right hand and a silver jar in her left, creating steady streams onto the earth. A luminous butterfly prepares to land on a rose. The scene's illumination is dim, with contours more suggested than distinct.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XVIII: Hierarquia Oculta, O Crepúsculo, A Lua (The Moon)
structure_content.summary: The background is a bare, desolate plain that merges imperceptibly with a starless twilight sky. In the far distance, two dimly visible pyramids emerge from the enveloping mist. A waning but almost full moon illuminates the plain with silver rays, revealing a narrow, winding path that traverses the landscape, disappearing into the mist between the pyramids. Dark spots, identified as pools of blood, are clearly visible on the path. In the foreground, a small lagoon contains a black crab with clenched pincers, emerging but returning to the water. Further back, a dog on the right and a wolf on the left sit, howling at the moon. The image evokes a somber impression, with dark tones. Only the wolf, dog, crab, and bloodstains are clearly delineated; the rest is semi-obscured.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XIX: Luz Resplandecente, O Sol (The Sun)
structure_content.summary: A semicircular wall of well-fitted marble cubes limits a grassy lawn. On the lawn, two children, approximately seven years old, a boy and a girl, run hand-in-hand. Their faces show no planetary influences, only innocence and purity. The sun rises behind the wall, in the middle of the frame, its rays flooding the space and transforming into a golden rain. The children gaze at the rays; the boy raises his arm to reach an unconsolidated golden ray, while the girl bends forward, extending her hand to collect a gold coin from the grass. The entire picture suggests abundant light and air, joy, purity, and springtime.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XX: Ressurreição dos mortos, Atração divina, O Julgamento (Judgment)
structure_content.summary: The background is a tilled field under a sky with light clouds, in an overall lilac-violet tone. In the sky, a snow-white angel hovers, blowing a golden trumpet, its left arm extended in an inviting gesture. In the foreground, an open tomb reveals a human family emerging from the earth. A man, already standing beside the tomb, stretches his arms towards the angel. A woman, half-emerged from the earth, holds up a child who reaches for the angel. All three figures are nude and surrounded by a mystical lilac aura. The scene is illuminated by the angel's bright, dazzling white light.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XXI: Furca, O Louco (The Fool)
structure_content.summary: The card features rocky mountains, with a large green lizard hiding on a cliff on the left, looking up with an open mouth, awaiting a victim. A ragged man with undefined, colorless clothes walks from right to left among the rocks, casting a shadow ahead. A dog chases him, tearing the lower part of his clothing, exposing his leg. The man's left hand holds a staff horizontally in the middle of its length, while his right hand supports a long staff over his shoulder, from which an informe, heavy bundle hangs. He wears a hood, and his face is turned away, invisible, but his head is slightly raised as if looking at the sky. The contours of the image are sharp, with clear lines and subdued colors. (Note: Mebes assigns the number 21 to The Fool, traditionally unnumbered or 0).

structure_content.chapter_title: Lâmina XXII: Coroa Mágica, O Mundo (The World)
structure_content.summary: At the center of the image is a vertical ellipse formed by a green Uroboros, the Egyptian serpent, biting its own tail with its head downwards. Within the ellipse, against a radiant golden background, a naked dancing girl appears. Her right foot's toes lightly rest on the serpent's head, and her loose brown hair cascades down her body. Her face is joyful and triumphant. Her arms are slightly bent, and her hands hold two perfectly equal hazelnut wands at the same height, parallel to each other. In the four corners of the card, outside the ellipse and against a white background, are the heads of the four Hermetic animals: the eagle (top right), the bull (top left), the lion (bottom right), and the austere face of an angel (bottom left). All gaze towards the center of the card. (Note: Mebes assigns the number 22 to The World, traditionally 21).

key_concepts.definition: A unique Tarot deck and interpretative system derived from G.O. Mebes' 'Curso de Enciclopédia do Ocultismo', distinguished by its specific symbolism, numbering (e.g., The Fool as XXI, The World as XXII), and rich Hermetic-Qabalistic and astrological attributions for the Major Arcana.

The source material for the G.O. Mebes Tarot interpretations, based on G.O. Mebes' lectures in S. Petersburg (1911-1912) and first published in Shanghai in 1937, featuring detailed descriptions and illustrations of the Major Arcana.

A core principle in Mebes' system, positing that the Tarot card images act as a mirror, reflecting reality. This concept influences how descriptions are formulated, often noting that the depicted 'right arm' of a figure corresponds to the figure's anatomical 'left arm', requiring a specific interpretive orientation.

The primary focus of this specific presentation, with each Major Arcana card attributed multiple esoteric titles and detailed symbolic explanations, suggesting layers of meaning for spiritual development and understanding.

A recurrent theme throughout the descriptions, where figures and scenes on the cards are explicitly linked to planetary archetypes (e.g., The Magician embodying characteristics of seven planets, The Empress as Venus Urania, The Emperor as Jupiterian, The Star as Mercurian, The Devil with lunar phases), emphasizing an astrological dimension to the Tarot's symbolism.

An explicit concept directly referenced in the interpretation of Lâmina XII, 'O Sacrifício' (The Hanged Man), where the figure's position forms 'the cross above the inverted triangle,' symbolizing a fundamental process of alchemical or spiritual transformation.

Various symbols deeply embedded in Hermetic and alchemical traditions, such as the caduceus, Uroboros, pentagrams, solar crosses, and the four Hermetic animals (eagle, bull, lion, angel), are integral to the visual language and esoteric meaning of the G.O. Mebes Tarot.

practical_system.description: While not an explicit step-by-step magical grimoire, the G.O. Mebes system, as presented through these detailed Arcana descriptions, constitutes a profound framework for contemplation and symbolic interpretation. The depth of analysis provided for each card, incorporating planetary influences, alchemical principles (e.g., the Great Work), and archetypal figures, suggests a method of spiritual introspection and self-initiation. The 'reflection of reality' principle is key, implying that the practitioner must engage with the imagery as a mirror to inner and outer forces, using the cards as keys to unlock deeper understanding of cosmic and personal truths. The system is less about performing external rituals and more about internalizing the profound symbolic narratives for personal transformation and esoteric knowledge.
tools: G.O. Mebes Tarot deck (specifically the Major Arcana)
Personal Journal (for recording insights and contemplations)

relevant_quotes.text: As lâminas, em geral, apresentam o reflexo da realidade, tal como aparece num espelho; portanto, por exemplo, o braço direito da figura é, efetivamente, seu braço esquerdo. As descrições, neste sentido, sempre se referem à figura da imagem.
O quadro, no seu conjunto, dá uma impressão profundamente real, embora não concretizada demasiadamente.
Foi graças a dois estudiosos russos do Tarô - Andriy Kostenko e Victor Olsufiev - que se tornou possível apresentar, nesta galeria do Clube do Tarô, as lâminas do "Tarô GOM".
Mebes atribui o número 21 ao Louco (usualmente sem número) e o 22 ao Mundo (usualmente 21).
A posição geral da figura delineia claramente o símbolo da Grande Obra, ou seja, a cruz acima do triângulo invertido.
A impressão geral é triste e pesada. As cores monótonas e deprimentes, quase apagadas. Na figura da Morte, nenhuma expressão.
O quadro dá uma impressão geral profundamente triste e desalentadora.

critical_analysis.relevance: The G.O. Mebes Tarot is highly relevant within Western Esotericism for its distinctive Hermetic-Qabalistic framework and rich, detailed symbolism that deviates significantly from more common Tarot systems (e.g., Waite-Smith or Thoth). Its non-standard numbering and explicit planetary/alchemical attributions offer a unique perspective on the Major Arcana, making it a valuable subject for historical research into early 20th-century Russian occultism and an intriguing alternative for advanced practitioners. The emphasis on 'reflection of reality' as an interpretative principle provides a unique methodological approach to Tarot readings and contemplation.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is primarily aimed at experienced occultists, academic researchers in Western Esotericism, historians of Tarot, and advanced practitioners of Hermetic Qabalah or Chaos Magic who seek alternative and deeply symbolic Tarot systems. Its complex and specific interpretations, along with its unique numbering and symbolic language, make it unsuitable for beginners in Tarot or occult studies.
